ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We mainly had virtual seminars with synchronized classes. There were occasional discussion posts due before class.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I improved my critical reading and writing skills through exercises in close reading, archival research, and interpretive debate, and learned about self-expression and identity in American Literature.
I significantly improved and developed my analytical skills towards literature and especially my writing capabilities for close reading analysis and papers.
Improved my writing and critical reading skills, learnt about American literature in depth

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Smith worked very hard to make this course engaging despite the circumstances of this semester. I appreciated that he formatted our class discussions in a way that gave everyone an opportunity to participate, and I looked forward to going to every class. I enjoyed all of the books that we read and our class discussions and papers helped me to develop a deeper understanding of their meaning. I am very glad that I took this course and can't think of any weaknesses.
Too small a class. Conversations lagged, and professor/format wasn't very conducive to open discussion.

In general I feel like we did not have enough time to talk about the books. Often I would read nearly 100 pages just to speak for about 5 minutes total. For a discussion based class, I really just wished there was more student participation allowed and encouraged.

The way Professor Smith moderated discussions was definitely the biggest strength because it was a good combination of giving opportunity to the students to speak while also providing a lot of insight.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having our class discussions over zoom worked very well. Everyone had their cameras on which helped me to feel engaged and Professor Smith led our class discussions in a way that gave everyone the opportunity to participate.

I think overall the course went well with the virtual adjustments. The assignments online and discussion posts were fine. Zoom conferences can be a bit awkward at times but for the most part felt natural.
Virtual seminar format succeeded. It would have been improved by a virtual field trip (to the Beinecke/Art Gallery).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to students looking for an introductory English course. This course was accessible to non-English majors and my close reading and critical writing skills improved significantly. Professor Smith was very thoughtful and gave everyone an opportunity to participate each class. Our discussions were always engaging and I enjoyed all of the books we read.

I would recommend this course. Overall a really nice class with some powerful discussions that I enjoyed. There is a good amount of reading, but ultimately what you get from this class is dependent on your effort.

Yes, both to English majors and non-majors! This was a good starting point for any student to improve their reading and writing skills, but it also provided English majors great insight into works of American literature.
